physDesc.p: Two pages typewritten in black ink. Address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page: Mrs. Richard Aldington care Manager, Lloyd’s Bank, 67 Kingsway, London W.C.2, England. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Your letter of March sixth was very nice to get. I do not advise your having the "Keats" sent to the continent if you are running round, for he is really very bulky, and you can get it when you come to London.
Mrs. Russell and I land in England on April twenty-first, and we sail for home on July eighteenth, so that gives us a good leeway; in case you come to England, I am almost sure to be there.
Jonathan Cape has done nobly with the lectures, and I am booked for about twenty readings – at all the English universities and before various poetry societies, etc.

If you think that the London reviews of the "Keats" are good, that is not my idea of good. On the other hand, the provincial papers and the Scottish papers have been really good. The London papers, in spite of the space that they have allowed me, have adopted their usual sneering tactics, but their interest to hear me speak is surprising. I am giving a lecture at Birmingham University on "Modern American Poetry" and shall read some of your things there. I feel that it is really going back ten years and expect to be greeted with potatoes and rotten eggs. But, as far as I can make out, it is the literary set who are hostile, the public at large seem well enough disposed. Poets are a jealous crowd, and when I saw Edith Sitwell patronizing you and me in "Vogue" the other day, I could not help smiling.

I have not seen the collected edition of your books published by Boni and Liveright, but I am very anxious to get it. The English can talk as they want, but I think the American poets beat them all to a frazzle, and I expect to hint as much, gently but firmly, in my lecture.

I am sending this to the bank so that you may receive it somewhere, some time. I wrote to Winifred Bryher the other day and sent my book to her South Audley Street address. I hope she will get it sometime.

I did not send you any royalties from the Imagist anthologies in February for the simple reason that there were none. 1915 and 1916 are out of print and there are only six copies of 1917 left, so we shall soon have done with it altogether. It did its work and served its turn, and I, for one, shall be glad to have it entirely disposed of.

Both Mrs. Russell and I are looking forward very much to seeing you. We shall be at the Berkley Hotel, but my bank address will probably be safer. It is care of Messrs. Brown, Shipley & Co., 123 Pall Mall, London, S.W.
